We Care!
Employees of the Oneonta City School District would like your assistance with showing our Health Care and EMS Workers that "We Care" about the sacrifices they're making on a daily basis.

We would like to send our HEROES letters, pictures, poems and messages that can be displayed in areas that they pass by on their way to work each day. The Yellowjacket Art teachers will be rolling out a project that students will be working on the week of April 13th and we'd like to extend the offer to members of our community. Please pass the link along to family members, neighbors and help us create the excitement that is needed during these trying times. Your message can be sent to wecare@oneontacsd.org by email, as a picture from your camera or as a pdf / jpeg attachment. OCSD students may submit their art work by navigating to https://bit.ly/OCSDCares, where they will log in with their Google account and upload their art work.

Once a week, we'll print off the work at school and follow proper guidance from our Health care works as to not put them at risk of contamination.

Bravo to all of you for what you've collectively created there! I so look forward to when our paths will cross again!

Oneonta City School District names Oneonta High School Baseball facility as the:
“JOE HUGHES FIELD”
At the September 11, 2019 Board of Education Meeting Superintendent, Thomas Brindley announced that the OHS baseball facility will be known as the “Joe Hughes Field”. Mr. Joe Hughes has served the Oneonta City School District and the Oneonta community for 35 years as a teacher, coach, and athletic director. Mr. Brindley stated; “The list of titles that Joe has donned is a lengthy one. However, his impact on our school district has been exceptional. During his 21 year tenure as athletic director, he was driven to provide the athletes of Oneonta with the best possible student-athlete experience. He worked to create the best possible facilities, hire the best coaches, and create a top-notch athletic program.”
Congratulations to Mr. Joe Hughes!!

post_text: Our schools don't just support our students' learning - we know it's also important to support the whole child and, when we can, the whole family. The hygiene closet at Riverside Elementary is just one example of how our schools work to support families. In addition, our students are learning what it means to be part of a community by working together to care for one another. We are so grateful for all the support that this and other programs receive from the community ❤️❤️
shared_text:
Riverside Elementary Principal- Oneonta NY
April 23, 2019 at 9:30 AM ·

What many people may not realize is that federally funded food stamps can't be used to purchase hygiene products. Recognizing our mission to support families holistically, in addition to our food pantry we recently opened our, "Look good - Feel good - Be good" hygiene closet. The closet is run by Mrs. Stanton's 3rd, 4th, and 5th grade students. They stock shelves, pack bags, and distribute the hygiene bags once a month to almost 40 Riverside families.
